Navigation
Name Recipes/Common/Crawl
Synopsis Crawl a file system and collect files with given extension
Description A Web Crawler is a program that browses web pages in a systematic manner. Here we present a crawler for files in a file system, although it can easily be extended to browse the web as well.
Examples 
module demo::common::Crawl

import IO;
import String;

public list[loc] crawl(loc dir, str suffix){
  res = [];
  for(str entry <- listEntries(dir)){
      loc sub = dir + entry;   
      if(isDirectory(sub)) {
          res += crawl(sub, suffix);
      } else {
	      if(endsWith(entry, suffix)) { 
	         res += [sub]; 
	      }
      }
  };
  return res;
}

//public list[loc] crawl2(loc dir, str suffix){
//  return 
//	  for(str entry <- listEntries(dir)){
//	      loc sub = dir + entry;  
//	      if(isDirectory(sub)) {
//	          append crawl(sub, suffix);  
//	      } else {
//		      if(endsWith(entry, suffix)) { 
//		         append [sub];           
//		      }
//	      }
//	  };
//}

public list[loc] crawl3(loc dir, str suffix) =
  isDirectory(dir) ? [*crawl(e,suffix) | e <- dir.ls] : (dir.extension == suffix ? [dir] : []);
The crawl function takes two arguments:
  • The directory dir where the crawl should start.
  • The suffix of the files we are looking for.
The crawler simply lists all entries in the current directory using Rascal:listEntries and adds all files that end we the given suffix to the result. If an entry is itself a directory, it is crawled by a recursive call to crawl. At we use concatenation on a location and a string; it automatically adds a / separator, see ambiguous: Rascal:Location for details.

We also show shorter versions crawl2 and crawl3 that we further discuss below.

Let's now crawl the demo files used in this course: 
rascal>import demo::common::Crawl;
ok
rascal>files = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>): IO("Unsupported scheme bundleresource")
	at *** somewhere ***(|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>))
	at listEntries(|rascal://demo::common::Crawl|(486,3,<17,31>,<17,34>))
	at ___SCREEN_INSTANCE___(|stdin:///|(8,36,<1,8>,<1,44>))
This list can be the starting point for further investigation, for instance, to compute the number of files; 
rascal>import List;
ok
rascal>size(files);
|stdin:///|(5,5,<1,5>,<1,10>): Undeclared variable: files
or to compute the total number of lines in these files: 
rascal>import IO;
ok
rascal>(0 | it + size(readFileLines(f)) | loc f <- files);
|stdin:///|(44,5,<1,44>,<1,49>): Undeclared variable: files
This above example uses a Rascal:Reducer expression.

Finally, we can look for the largest files. First import some libraries we will need. 
rascal>import Relation;
ok
rascal>import Set;
ok
Create a relation aux of <location, length> pairs: 
rascal>aux = {<f, size(readFileLines(f))> | loc f <- files};
|stdin:///|(46,5,<1,46>,<1,51>): Undeclared variable: files
Now determine the maximum length (using Rascal:size), by taking the maximum of the Rascal:range of aux: 
rascal>m = max(range(aux));
|stdin:///|(14,3,<1,14>,<1,17>): Undeclared variable: aux
and now Rascal:invert aux and use Rascal:Subscription to find the tuples with the maximum value as first element. 
rascal>invert(aux)[m];
|stdin:///|(7,3,<1,7>,<1,10>): Undeclared variable: aux
In the listing given above, there are two alternative versions of crawl:
  • crawl2 uses Rascal:Append (at and ) to avoid introducing a local variable res as done in crawl.
  • crawl3 is the shortest version that depends on a list comprehension and on the ls field of locations.
Let's try them: 
rascal>import demo::common::Crawl;
ok
rascal>files2 = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>): IO("Unsupported scheme bundleresource")
	at *** somewhere ***(|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>))
	at listEntries(|rascal://demo::common::Crawl|(486,3,<17,31>,<17,34>))
	at ___SCREEN_INSTANCE___(|stdin:///|(9,36,<1,9>,<1,45>))


rascal>files3 = crawl(|std://library/demo|, ".rsc");
|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>): IO("Unsupported scheme bundleresource")
	at *** somewhere ***(|rascal://IO|(7072,344,<272,0>,<288,44>))
	at listEntries(|rascal://demo::common::Crawl|(486,3,<17,31>,<17,34>))
	at ___SCREEN_INSTANCE___(|stdin:///|(9,36,<1,9>,<1,45>))
and verify that the two lists are identical: 
rascal>files2 == files3;
|stdin:///|(0,6,<1,0>,<1,6>): Undeclared variable: files2
